Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reconstruction of Environmental Conditions and Human Occupancy Associated with Semi-Polar Settlements

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate why previously thriving Norse settlements in Greenland collapsed or were abandoned in the early 15th century. The project will provide new insights into the regional paleoenvironment of southwest coastal Greenland as well as how past societies responded to environmental change. It will provide a test of competing hypotheses, some of which posited that the settlements collapsed because of deteriorating climatic conditions associated with the onset of Little Ice Age cooling, but others have argued that the Norse Greenlander settlements were victims of cultural and socioeconomic factors unrelated to environmental conditions. More broadly, the project will enhance understanding of societal fragility in the face of ecological change, and it may provide new knowledge that can be employed by the Danish and Inuit residents of this region as well as residents of other semi-polar environments in the U.S. and elsewhere. The project will provide an excellent education and training opportunity for an undergraduate research assistant. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The project will seek to identify what environmental conditions may have contributed to the collapse of the Norse settlements in Greenland. The doctoral student will analyze high-resolution records of human occupancy, temperature, and precipitation using organic geochemical proxies, also known as biomarkers, which were extracted from lacustrine sedimentary archives adjacent to Norse ruins at three locations in southwestern Greenland. He will reconstruct the history of human occupancy and paleoenvironmental conditions at a multi-decadal scale for the past 1,500 to 2,000 years. He also will analyze human biomarkers to reconstruct shifts in dietary patterns as a response to changing environmental conditions. The project will blend geography, geology, archaeology, and geochemistry to produce findings that include the integration of paleoenvironmental and human occupancy reconstructions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cause of the demise of the Norse in Greenland during the 15th century has long been the subject of debate. Some researchers have argued that cooling associated with “the Little Ice Age” was the likely cause of the collapse of the colony, while others have suggested instead that the Norse were undone by external socio-economic and political factors that were beyond their control. To date, a satisfactory resolution of this matter has been hampered by the lack of local records of either temperature or precipitation from the Norse settlement regions in SW Greenland. Many of the previous arguments have been based on ice core records from the summit of the Greenland ice sheet, hundreds of miles away from where the Norse were living.

The goal of this project was therefore to provide on-site climatic information, by analyzing lake sediments from in and around the Norse settlements, to reconstruct climate during the time of colonization and the subsequent settlement demise (Figure 1).  The temperature reconstruction from Eriksvatnet (the site where Erik the Red is thought to have established his farm) is based on specific organic molecules called branched glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers, or brGDGTs. These compounds are produced by bacteria, and the distribution of these brGDGTs in sediments has previously been shown to be related to local air temperature. Our record from Eriksvatnet lake (Figure 2) is one of the first biomarker based temperature reconstructions from Greenland.

The temperature reconstruction from Eriksvatnet (Figure 3) suggests that the Norse arrived in Greenland during a period of relatively warm temperatures, and that temperatures were declining during the period of abandonment in the 15th century. It must be noted here however, that the dating of this lake sediment record has proven to be highly challenging; it is based on a radiocarbon chronology, but some samples have yielded reversed, or out of order, dates, which reduces our confidence in the timing of events.  We are actively pursuing other methods of dating to improve the chronology, and initial investigations of Icelandic volcanic ash particles (of known age) that occur in the sediments have been promising. Nevertheless, despite the dating uncertainty, it does appear that the Norse demise was accompanied by cooling temperatures at this site, though the climate deterioration took place over several centuries.  By combining the results from Eriksvatnet with data from other lakes in the area (currently under investigation) we hope to clarify this preliminary picture, and obtain a clearer understanding of what local climate was doing when the Norse colonization ended.

This Doctoral Dissertation award has led to a thesis chapter in the completed PhD of Gregory de Wet, along with a scientific article that is in preparation for a peer-reviewed journal. Additionally, it formed the basis of the senior honors thesis of University of Massachusetts, Amherst undergraduate student Thomas Barrasso, who was supervised by de Wet. Both Barrasso and de Wet have presented their work at several professional meetings (the International Meeting of Organic Geochemistry, the Northeast regional meeting of the Geological Society of America, and the American Geophysical Union meeting). De Wet also worked with the University of Massachusetts, Amherst to produce press releases and a short movie describing his work in SW Greenland; this includes interviews and drone photographic footage. The video is publicly available on the University of Massachusetts, Amherst website: http://www.umass.edu/newsoffice/article/umass-amherst-geoscientists-reconstruct-0.
